WebIOPi UI customization is easy but requires some CSS knowledge. The basic technic is to hide all controls, then show and move wanted controls. You will also need to add a Javascript line for each button you want to change the label.

<font color="red>*Before starting, copy webiopi.html to mypage.html and create a new blank mypage.css*</font>

RPi pins and direction buttons are all html inputs, and inherit the _input_ CSS style.
There is also some class to modify generic controls :
  * .DNC : Do not connect
  * .GND : Ground
  * .V33 : 3.3V
  * .V50 : 5.0V
  * .LOW : GPIO in low state
  * .HIGH : GPIO in high state
  * .UART
  * .SPI
  * .I2C

  * .pinDirection_Enabled : Direction button for enabled GPIOs
  * .pinDirection_Disabled : Direction button for disabled GPIOs
  * .pinName : Name on the left/right of each pin

To hide all controls, override and add "visibility: hidden" to _input_ selector, and to both .pinDirection_Enabled and .pinName CSS classes. This is also a good place to set the absolute positionning and we can add any property that will be shared between _input_ controls : solid border, no padding, white text color and no webkit appearance.
{{{
input {
        visibility: hidden;
        position: absolute;
        border: black 3px solid;
        padding: 0 0 0 0;
        color: white;
        -webkit-appearance: none;
}

.pinDirection_Enabled {
        visibility: hidden;
}

.pinDirection_Disabled {
        visibility: hidden;
}

.pinName {
        visibility: hidden;
}
}}}

Then, you can use a selector to show and modify each desired pin by using their IDs while inheriting from _input_:
{{{
#pin3 {
        visibility: visible;
        top: 20px;
        left: 20px;
        width: 80px;
        height: 80px;
        font-size: 24pt;
        font-weight: bold;
}

#pin26 {
        visibility: visible;
        top: 120px;
        left: 20px;
        width: 80px;
        height: 80px;
        font-size: 24pt;
        font-weight: bold;
        color: black;
}

#pin26.LOW {
        background-color: white;
}

#pin26.HIGH {
        background-color: red;
}

}}}
will display the RPi pin 3 (GPIO 0) and 26 (GPIO 7), with two bigs buttons in the upper-left corner. It also changes the background color of the PIN 26 for both low and high states.

In your HTML file, replace the title, change the link tag with webiopi.css to point to your CSS. You also have to add some Javascript next to the CSS link :
{{{
<title>My Page</title>
<script type="text/javascript" src="jquery.js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript" src="webiopi.js"></script>
<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="mypage.css" />
<script type="text/javascript">
$(document).ready(function() {
	postDirection(3, "in"); // set RPi pin 3 (GPIO 0) to input
	setPinLabel(3, "SW");  // change the label

	postDirection(26, "out"); // set RPi pin 3 (GPIO 7) to output
	setPinLabel(26, "LED");  // change the label
});
</script>
}}}

Then open a browser by appending mypage.html to the usual URL (http://raspberrypi/webiopi/mypage.html) and you will see 2 big controls.
